title: Do authors make a commission off of every single sale of their novels? - Quora

response.answer_text: We don’t make commissions, we earn royalties. “Commission” implies you’re working for someone else, and novelists aren’t. As for whether we earn royalties off every single sale, it’s not quite a simple “yes” or “no.” Usually, if a novel is traditionally published, the publisher has paid the author a lump sum up front called an “advance against royalties.” Every single copy the publisher sells at or above wholesale does indeed earn royalties, but the author doesn’t receive anything more until the royalties earned exceed the amount paid as an advance. The book is indeed earning royalties, but the author already got paid. Once the full advance has been earned, then the author does indeed get paid for every copy sold — except see below. Traditionally, the publisher would send a royalty statement twice a year, listing how many copies had sold, and enclosing a check for anything above the amount of the advance… except for a reserve against returns, which is money the publisher holds back until it’s sure bookstores aren’t going to return more copies than they sell. (You know books are returnable for credit, right?) Anyway, short version, the accounting can get complicated, but yes, every copy sold earns the author a royalty, with the following exceptions: Review copies and copies given away for publicity are not sales, and therefore don’t pay royalties. When a book goes out of print — that is, when the publisher isn’t printing any more copies and decides the remaining copies on hand aren’t selling fast enough to justify the warehouse space they’re taking up — the remaining copies can be disposed of two different ways. They can be destroyed, or they can be sold off below cost. Books sold off below cost are called “remainders,” because they’re what remained in the warehouse after the book’s commercial life was over. Authors do not earn royalties on books sold as remainders. It also used to be that Braille editions and other books for the blind didn’t earn royalties, but since audiobooks have caught on I don’t know whether that still applies. Generally, Braille editions were done as a public service, and the publisher didn’t make money on them — they’re more expensive to produce, and sales are very low. Publishers understandably didn’t want to pay the author for books that were already losing them money. So giveaways, remainders, and editions for the blind don’t earn royalties. But every single book sold through normal channels does earn the author a royalty.

It depends on the situation. If there’s a contract, it might specify certain kinds of sales that the author won’t get a royalty for. The author might earn royalties but they will be applied to whatever advance the author got. If a book is written “for hire,” the author might only get the initial pre-launch payments until the book is completed, unless it was negotiated to get a bonus or percentage if sales exceed a certain number. Obviously, there is no royalty to the author on second-hand sales. Sales to libraries may also be exempted by the contract. (If the publisher can avoid paying royalties on those, which are virtually guaranteed regardless of quality or popularity of the work even if not a single copy is sold anywhere else, why would they pay them? Business is business.) Sometimes, a bookseller has a lot of unsold copies they want to return to the publisher, but the publisher doesn’t want them back (doesn’t want to pay the freight and can’t sell them anyway), so they credit the bookseller’s account with the return and tell them to just sell them. Those are the books you’ll see on the “CLEARANCE” tables at Barnes and Noble for $5 when the cover price was $24.99 a month ago, or they may sell them to a large second-hand bookseller, such as Red Carpet.
